results.title: Clara Gibbings
results.creator_credit: F.W. Thring and Efftee Film Productions
results.brief_description: This production was adapted from the play of the same name and remained basically a filmed stage play. Dorothy Brunton plays Clara Gibbings, the proprietor of a London pub, who discovers that she is the legitimate but abandoned daughter of the Earl of Dunmoor. She launches herself into high society but soon grows disillusioned and decides to return to the fresh air of her own class. A young aristocrat, Errol, has meanwhile learnt to respect Clara and to see his own decadent life in a new light. Impulsively he proposes marriage and they depart for Australia.

results.title: Chungking express
results.creator_credit: Chan Yi-Kan, Jet Tone Production and Wong
results.brief_description: Director Wong Kar-Wai, working again with cinematographer Christopher Doyle brings together two loosely connected stories of unrequited love, drug smuggling, fast-food joints and melancholic cops. Revisiting his regular themes of chance vs fate and broken hearted loners, Wong Kar-Wai and Doyle (sharing his DOP duties with Lau Wai-Keung), again have created a heightened world of neon drenched cities and smokey bars, while the soundtrack repeats it’s ethereal refrain of the Mamas and the Papas California dreaming. The first story centers around the infamous Chungking mansions as a lovelorn cop, identified as No.223 (Takeshi Kaneshiro) yearns over a mysterious woman (Brigitte Lin) in dark sunglasses and a Marilyn Monroe style wig. Unbeknownst to the sombre detective, who has a peculiar nostalgic attachment to crushed canned pineapple, the woman is working on the other side of the law as a small time heroin smuggler. The second randomly linked story is set around the Midnight Express fast-food joint where cop No.663 (Tony Leung) spends most of his nights, recovering over a break up with an air hostess (Valerie Chow), unaware that the young woman who works behind the counter (Hong Kong rock star Faye Wong) is quietly infatuated with him. In Cantonese and Mandarin with English subtitles.

constellations_other.name: Wong Kar-Wai's Hollywood fingerprints
constellations_other.description: Wong Kar-wai’s modern masterpiece In The Mood For Love is a rich, romantic melodrama that follows the entangled lives of two neighbours (Tony Leung and Maggie Cheung) who develop feelings for each other after learning their spouses are having an affair.

results.title: Chronopolis
results.brief_description:
Chronopolis is a city lost in space. The inhabitants are immortal and they attempt to relieve their boredom by manufacturing time. They are all awaiting a liberating cataclysm which will break the monotony of their endless lives. During one of their manufactured moments, the Chronossians meet a human being in the person of a mountaineer.

Credits: Producer, Marcelle Ponti ; director, Piotr Kamler ; writer, Piotr Kamler, Gabrielle Althen ; photography, Piotr Kamler ; music, Luc Ferrari.
Cast: Michel Lonsdale [narration].

results.title: Chouans! (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Ariel Zeitoun and Philippe De Broca
results.brief_description:
Aristocrat, philosopher and inventor, Count Savinien de Kerfadec loses his wife as she gives birth to their daughter, Celine. The same night he brings home Aurele, a newborn he found of the doorstep of the church. A few years later, young Tarquin who is on his way to the seminar, runs away and becomes the third addition to the eccentric Kerfadec household. As the children grow up, a love triangle develops, until the day the boys are sent away to make their way in the world. In 1793, Tarquin comes back to Brittany as a representant of the Republic, in charge of repressing the uprising in the Western provinces and possibly woe Celine. But Aurele and Celine, whose love for each other has blossomed, are active among those called ‘Les Chouans’.

Credits: Producer, Ariel Zeitoun ; director, Philippe de Broca ; writers, Daniel Boulanger, Philippe de Brocca, Jerome Tonnerre ; photography, Bernard Zitzermann ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Sopphie Marceau, Lambert Wilson, Philippe Noiret, Stephane Freiss, Jean-Pierre Cassel, Roger Dumas.

results.title: Children of the revolution
results.creator_credit: Peter Duncan, Tristram Miall and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: ‘Children of the Revolution’ is a delightful comedy which takes an irreverent look at political idealism. When Joan Fraser (Judy Davis), a zealous communist, visits Stalin in Moscow it’s the height of the Menzies era. She returns to Australia pregnant. Could her Stalinist love child change the course of Australian history? Wonderful performances from Judy Davis and Sam Neill (in an ironic twist on their roles in ‘My Brilliant Career’!) as well as Geoffrey Rush, Richard Roxburgh, Rachel Griffiths and F. Murray Abraham as Stalin.

results.title: Children of Soong Ching Ling
results.brief_description: Deals with the founding in China of orphanages and other welfare agencies to alleviate the suffering of millions of children. The social and cultural wellbeing of the children since 1948 are highlighted.

results.title: Chariots of fire
results.brief_description: Historical drama based on a true story of two members of Britain’s 1924 Olympic team, Harold Abrahams, a Jew running to prove himself in the face of the subtle hostility he found in his British environment, and Eric Liddell, a deeply religious man who refused to run on the Sabbath. Academy Award winner for Best Picture.

results.title: Catuor
results.creator_credit: Pierre Heberrt, ONF | NFB and Judith Klein
results.brief_description: This film is about cats - actually, one very clever cat. The title is a play on the French “quatuor” meaning quartet, but the chorus is not the usual alley cat variety. The cat in this film is talented indeed. It is both pianist and piano, trumpet and trumpeter, and, if need be, even becomes the music - a pulsing rock and roll - or a whole swarm of alley cats. Award: Madrid

results.title: Casablanca (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Hal B Wallis, Warner Bros Pictures and Michael Curtiz
results.brief_description: Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman portray former lovers briefly reunited amid the chaos of World War II. The film tells of the lonely owner of a nightclub in Nazi-occupied Casablanca and of the brief return of his former lover fleeing the Nazis with her resistance-hero husband. Only Bogart can help them escape, but he refuses…until Ilsa reawakens his idealism. Also stars Paul Henreid, Claude Rains, Sydney Greenstreet, Peter Lorre and Conrad Veidt. An all-time classic. This version of the film has been restored and digitally remastered. Also included is a documentary on the making of this classic, “You must remember this”, narrated by Lauren Bacall, as well as the 1942 original theatrical trailer and the 1992 re-issue theatrical trailer, and an all-new introduction by Lauren Bacall.

results.title: Carrington
results.creator_credit: Christopher Hampton, John McGrath, Ronald Shedlo and Dora Productions
results.brief_description: Dora Carrington (Emma Thompson) devotes her life to writer Lytton Strachey (Jonathan Pryce) a tall, thin, bearded bachelor and member of London’s famed Bloomsbury artistic set. Even though their desire for each other was strong, their relationship was purely based on friendship, a bond that lives until the very end. This is one of the most unusual love stories you will ever see.
